IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: AMERICAN FORESTS PROTECTS AND RESTORES FORESTS, PRESERVING THE HEALTH OF OUR PLANET AND THE WELL-BEING OF ITS INHABITANTS.
IRS990.MissionDescription: AMERICAN FORESTS PROTECTS AND RESTORES FORESTS, PRESERVING THE HEALTH OF OUR PLANET AND THE WELL-BEING OF ITS INHABITANTS. FOUNDED IN 1875, THE ORGANIZATION HAS SERVED AS A CATALYST FOR MANY OF THE MOST IMPORTANT MILESTONES IN THE CONSERVATION MOVEMENT, INCLUDING THE FOUNDING OF THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE, THE NATIONAL FOREST AND PARK SYSTEMS, THE CREATION OF THE MODERN ENVIRONMENTAL MOVEMENT, AND SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENTS IN ENVIRONMENTAL LEGISLATION AND FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. SINCE 1990, AMERICAN FORESTS HAS PLANTED NEARLY 40 MILLION TREES IN FOREST ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECTS AROUND THE GLOBE, RESULTING IN CLEANER AIR AND DRINKING WATER, RESTORED HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE AND FISH, AND THE REMOVAL OF MILLIONS OF TONS OF CARBON FROM THE ATMOSPHERE.
IRS990.Description: GLOBAL RELEAF CENTER: AMERICAN FORESTS CREATED GLOBAL RELEAF IN 1990 AS AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND ACTION INITIATIVE TO ADDRESS THE GROWING NEED TO RESTORE DAMAGED AND DEGRADED ECOSYSTEMS THROUGH TREE PLANTING. SINCE THAT TIME, GLOBAL RELEAF HAS SUPPORTED PROJECTS THAT HAVE PLANTED MILLIONS OF TREES IN AREAS DAMAGED BY NATURAL CAUSES OR HUMAN ACTIVITY, IN EVERY STATE IN THE U.S. AND IN 38 COUNTRIES AROUND THE WORLD. WORKING WITH LOCAL PARTNERS, AMERICAN FORESTS HAS HELPED RESTORE AREAS THAT HAVE BEEN DEVASTATED BY MAJOR NATURAL DISTURBANCES, LIKE THE GULF COAST COMMUNITIES AFTER HURRICANE KATRINA, BY REPLANTING NEW TREES AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE. AND EACH YEAR, MANY OF OUR PROJECTS IN WESTERN FORESTS ARE AIMED AT REPLANTING AREAS THAT CAN NO LONGER REGENERATE NATURALLY BECAUSE OF HIGH-INTENSITY WILDFIRES. SOME PROJECTS ARE FOCUSED SPECIFICALLY ON PROVIDING FOOD AND SHELTER FOR BIRDS AND ANIMALS AS THEIR HABITATS ARE DESTROYED OR DEGRADED BY CLIMATE CHANGE, WILDFIRE, HUMAN ACTIVITY, OR A NUMBER OF OTHER CAUSES. WE ARE WORKING WITH HURON MANISTEE NATIONAL FOREST TO PLANT 402,000 TREES OVER 369 ACRES TO RESTORE THE UNIQUE HABITAT OF THE ENDANGERED KIRTLAND'S WARBLER. WE ARE ALSO WORKING TO REFOREST PARTS OF THE MICOACAN PRESERVE IN MEXICO TO RESTORE THE OYAMEL FIR FORESTS THAT THE MONARCH BUTTERFLY RELIES ON FOR WINTER HABITAT. WE ALSO ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIETAL NEEDS IN URBAN AREAS. IN CITIES, THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT OF A SINGLE TREE MAY BE PROPORTIONALLY MUCH GREATER THAN IN THE WILDERNESS. URBAN TREE-PLANTING PROJECTS MAY INCREASE THE FOREST CANOPY, PROVIDING SHADE TO HELP COOL AND BEAUTIFY URBAN NEIGHBORHOODS. EXPANDING THE URBAN FOREST ALSO ENHANCES THE CITY'S NATURAL WATER MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, SAVING CITY BUDGETS. SOME OTHER URBAN FOREST BENEFITS INCLUDE REDUCING AIR CONDITIONING COSTS BY SHADING A HEAT PUMP COMPRESSOR, FIGHTING THE EPIDEMIC OF CHILDHOOD ASTHMA BY CAPTURING PARTICULATE AIR POLLUTION, AND STORING CARBON FROM EMISSIONS. WE PROVIDE GRANTS TO LEVERAGE COMMUNITY RESOURCES FOR A VARIETY OF PROJECTS, INCLUDING STREAMSIDE FOREST BUFFERS, STREET TREES, AND OPEN-SPACE PLANTINGS.

Activity2.Description: URBAN CENTER: AMERICAN FORESTS HAS PARTNERED WITH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS FOR MORE THAN TWO DECADES ON A WIDE RANGE OF POLICY, EDUCATION, AND TREE-PLANTING ACTIVITIES TO DEVELOP THE FIELD AND PRACTICE OF URBAN FORESTRY, TO ADVANCE SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIETAL VALUES OF URBAN FORESTS, AND TO BUILD GREATER PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THESE VALUES AMONG CITY RESIDENTS AND POLICYMAKERS. OVER THE PAST 15 YEARS, AMERICAN FORESTS HAS CONDUCTED URBAN ECOSYSTEM ANALYSES IN MORE THAN 40 METROPOLITAN AREAS AROUND THE U.S., DOCUMENTING THE LOSS OF FOREST COVER AND ESTIMATING THE FINANCIAL VALUE OF THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT FORESTS PROVIDE.URBAN FORESTS ARE A VITAL PART OF FUNCTIONING URBAN ECOSYSTEMS AND SUSTAINABLE CITIES. URBAN FORESTS CAN SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE STORM WATER RUNOFF, ABSORB DANGEROUS CHEMICALS AND OTHER POLLUTANTS IN THE SOIL, REDUCE AIRBORNE POLLUTANTS, SEQUESTER AND STORE CARBON DIOXIDE, CONSERVE ENERGY THROUGH SHADING, PROVIDE URBAN BIRD AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR URBAN RESIDENTS. PORTLAND, OREGON, FOR EXAMPLE, IS TRYING TO INCREASE ITS URBAN FOREST CANOPY FROM 26 PERCENT OF THE CITY TO 33 PERCENT BY PLANTING 83,000 TREES TO HELP MANAGE STORM WATER AND FOR OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS. OTHER MAJOR CITIES - INCLUDING BOSTON, CHICAGO, LOS ANGELES, NEW YORK, AND PHOENIX - ALSO HAVE INITIATIVE TO INCREASE THEIR FOREST CANOPIES.

Activity3.Description: POLICY CENTER: AMERICAN FORESTS ADVOCATES FOR THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEMS. WE WORK WITH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO DEVELOP SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION ABOUT THE SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIETAL VALUES OF FORESTS AND WE COMMUNICATE THOSE VALUES TO THE PUBLIC AND POLICYMAKERS TO HEIGHTEN AWARENESS. WE SERVE AS A VOICE OF MODERATION ON FOREST POLICY ISSUES, ENCOURAGING CIVIL DIALOGUE AND OPEN, INCLUSIVE PROCESSES TOWARD FINDING COMMON-GROUND SOLUTIONS. WE ALSO HELP LOCAL PARTNERS IN RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY BUILD CAPACITY TO PARTICIPATE IN POLICY DECISION-MAKING AND TO DEVELOP DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS FOR COLLABORATIVE ACTION AND LEARNING.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: DESCRIPTION OF UNCERTAIN TAX POSITIONS UNDER FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: AF IS A NOT-FOR PROFIT ORGANIZATION INCORPORATED IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA AND IS EXEMPT FROM FEDERAL INCOME TAXES UNDER SECTION 501(C)(3) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. IT HAS BEEN DETERMINED THAT THE ORGANIZATION IS NOT A PRIVATE FOUNDATION AS DEFINED IN SECTION 509(A). AF IS SUBJECT TO UNRELATED BUSINESS INCOME TAX ON ANY NET ADVERTISING AND SALES REVENUE RELATED TO ITS PUBLICATIONS. AF DID NOT HAVE ANY MATERIAL UNRELATED BUSINESS INCOME FOR THE YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2010.

GrantsToOrgsOutsideUS.PurposeOfGrant: REFORESTATION FOR MONARCH BUTTERFLIES AND WATERSHED PROTECTION

Form990ScheduleFPartV.Identifier: PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING GRANTS OUTSIDE THE U.S.:
Form990ScheduleFPartV.Explanation: SCHEDULE F, PART I, LINE 2: GRANTS FUNDS ARE DISBURSED AFTER RECEIPT AND REVIEW OF FORMAL PROJECT REPORTS DETAILING THE COMPLETION OF PROJECTS. AFTER COMPLETION OF THE PROJECT, UPDATES ARE REQUESTED AND REVIEWED ANNUALLY FOR THE FIRST 3 YEARS AND EVERY 5 YEARS THEREAFTER.

RecipientTable.PurposeOfGrant: AMERICAN FORESTS FUNDED SEVERAL FORESTS SERVICE PROJECTS WHICH RANGED FROM HABITAT PROTECTION IN MICHIGAN FOR THE KIRTLAND'S WARBLER TO REFORESTING LANDS IN CALIFORNIA WHERE TREES WERE LOST TO FOREST FIRES. OVER 2,760,000 TREES WERE PLANTED THROUGH THE FOREST SERVICE.
AMERICAN FORESTS PLANTED 2000 CHESTNUT TREES WITH THE CAROL COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS FOR THE SCOTTIES RELEAF USA PROJECT.
THIS PROJECT PLANTED 21,500 HARDWOOD TREES IN AN INACTIVE AGRICULTURAL FIELD TO PROVIDE LARGER HABITATS FOR WILDLIFE AND IMPROVE FOREST HEALTH.

OVER THE COURSE OF THE PLANTING PERIOD KAE-CAG, THE ADNR AND VOLUNTEERS COLLECTIVELY PLANTED APPROXIMATELY 360,000 WILLOWS IN THE MAT-SU VALLEY MOOSE RANGE. THIS IS ONE OF ALASKA'S MOST DIVERSE ECOSYSTEMS AS IT DOES INCLUDE A RAIN FOREST.
THIS LONG RUNNING EFFORT TO REPLANT THE LOWER RIO GRANDE VALLEY PLANTED 199,712 TREES THIS SEGMENT. THIS REGION IS ONE OF THE MOST BIOLOGICALLY DIVERSE AREAS IN THE ALL NORTH AMERICA.
AMERICAN FORESTS FUNDED THIS PROJECT TO PLANT 89,429 TREES TO RESTORE FORESTS IN THE SAN BERNARDINO MOUNTAINS, WHICH HAVE LOST MILLIONS TO DROUGHT, FIRES, AND BARK BEETLE EPIDEMICS.
THE CONTINUATION OF THE 2009 EFFORT PLANTED 75,000 TREES IN 2010 TO REFOREST 2,600 ACRES OF LAND TO RE-ESTABLISH A SITKA SPRUCE FOREST.

RecipientNameBusiness.BusinessNameLine1: SHAWNEE RESOURCE CONSERVATION & DEVELOPMENT AREA INC

RecipientTable.PurposeOfGrant: THIS PROJECT IS PART OF A PLAN TO REFOREST 50,000 ACRES OF A DEFORESTED WETLAND COORIDOR IN THE CYPRESS CREEK NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, PROVIDING HABITAT FOR OVER 100 THREATENED OR ENDANGERED SPECIES.

THE GULF ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE WAS HIT BY MANY HURRICANES ALL BETWEEN THE YEARS OF 2004 AND 2008. THIS PROJECT REPLANTED THE DAMAGED NATURAL STANDS OF LONGLEAF PINES, SHORTLEAF PINES, SAND LIVE OAKS, WAX MYRTLES, AND DWARF SABAL PALM TREES, THIS PROJECT PLANTED 60,000 TREES IN ALL.

RecipientNameBusiness.BusinessNameLine1: STATE OF CALIFORNIA - DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND REC

RecipientTable.PurposeOfGrant: THE PROJECT AT CUYAMACA RANCHO STATE PARK IS DESIGNED TO RESTORE PORTIONS OF THE PARKS MIXED CONIFER FOREST WHICH WAS LOST IN THE 2003 CEDAR FIRE. IN ADDITION TO THIS, IT WILL SEQUESTER CARBON IN OUR FOREST TREES WHILE PROVIDING THE SPECTRUM OF ECOSYSTEM BENEFITS.

IN THIS SCOTTIES RELEAF USA PROJECT TREE PLANTINGS OCCURRED AT A TROPICAL MARITIME FOREST AT THE HISTORIC VIRGINIA KEY BEACH PARK. NATIVE TREES AND SHRUBS WERE PLANTED IN AN AREA THAT WAS ONCE DOMINATED BY AUSTRALIAN PINES.

WILDEARTH GUARDIANS AND AMERICAN FORESTS PLANTED OVER 65,000 NATIVE SHRUBS AND TREES IN THE HOPES OF RESTORING FUNCTION TO FOUR WATERSHEDS THAT HAVE BEEN DEGRADED BY OVERGRAZING, DESTABILIZED STREAMS, EXTREME TEMPERATURE FLUCTUATIONS, AND OTHER FACTORS.

IN 2010 THE FIRST PHASE OF THIS PROJECT WITH THE WORCESTER TREE INITIATIVE TOOK PLACE TO MEET ITS GOAL OF PLANTING 30,000 TREES OVER A FEW YEARS. THIS AREA WAS PARTICULARLY HIT HARD BY THE ASIAN LONGHORN BEETLE AND AN ICE STORM IN 2008.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: PROCEDURE FOR MONITORING GRANTS IN THE U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: SCHEDULE I, PART I, LINE 2: GLOBAL RELEAF GRANT AWARDS ARE REIMBURSABLE AWARDS FOR WHICH WE REQUEST AND RECEIVE A PROJECT REPORT FORM BEFORE PROVIDING PAYMENT TO GRANTEES. THE PROJECT REPORT FORM REQUESTS: 1. A NARRATIVE RESPONSE TO QUESTIONS ON WHETHER AND HOW WELL THE GRANTEE HAS CARRIED OUT THE PROPOSED GRANT ACTIVITIES; AND, 2. FINANCIAL AND BUDGET INFORMATION ON HOW THE REQUESTED GRANT AMOUNTS WERE EXPENDED, AS WELL AS INFORMATION ABOUT OTHER FUNDS AND SUPPORT DIRECTED TO THE PROJECT.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: SERVERANCE PAYMENTS WERE MADE TO THE FOLLOWING EMPLOYEES: DEBORAH GANGLOFF - $89,250 GARY MOLL - $70,000

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: AMERICAN FORESTS DISTRIBUTED A COPY OF THIS 990 TO ITS BOARD PRIOR TO FILING IT.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15A
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: CEO COMPENSATION REVIEW INCLUDED REVIEWING 990S OF SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS, INCLUDING THREE OF OUR TOP COMPETITORS: AMERICAN FOREST FOUNDATION, NATIONAL FOREST FOUNDATION, AND THE ARBOR DAY FOUNDATION. NON-PROFIT SALARY SURVEYS WERE ALSO CONSULTED.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 18
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE ORGANIZATION'S 990 IS MADE AVAILABLE ON ITS OWN WEBSITE, ANOTHER'S WEBSITE, AND UPON REQUEST. THE FORM 1023 AND 990-T ARE MADE AVAILABLE ONLY UPON REQUEST.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION C, LINE 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE ORGANIZATION MAKES ITS GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY, AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC UPON REQUEST.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: CHANGES IN NET ASSETS OR FUND BALANCES:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: NET UNREALIZED GAINS ON INVESTMENTS: 65,708. PRIOR PERIOD ADJUSTMENTS: 78,441. TOTAL TO FORM 990, PART XI, LINE 5: 144,149.
THERE HAVE BEEN NO CHANGES DURING THE YEAR IN THE PROCESS FOR OVERSIGHT OF THE AUDIT OF THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: WRITTEN DOCUMENT RETENTION AND DESTRUCTION POLICY
GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: FORM 990, PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 14
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A WRITTEN DOCUMENT RETENTION AND DESTRUCTION POLICY IS BEING CONSIDERED FOR IMPLEMENTATION IN THE CURRENT YEAR.
